@babeheim @anthrolog Unit tests are one of my favourite things about package writing, but I haven’t gotten in the habit of writing them systematically for analysis scripts (just a bunch of plots and tables to sense-check). I’d devour a blog post on it if you wrote one.

(And before anyone tries to explain to me how this can be done much more efficiently, I totally know, but the point of this exercise is to introduce power calculations through simulation using faux to #rstats beginners.)

Here's the first draft. I still need to check how the original paper handled directional hypotheses and corrections for the contrasts, but my simulation values are pretty similar to the re-analysis paper's values.

https://t.co/xru31f0Grj

@sharoz I'd like to keep the correction, but I'm not looking forward to teaching newbies how to wrangle the resulting table, as you need to turn the row names into a column and deal with the "Pr(<F)" column name somehow.

TIL that afex's returned anova_table uses GG corrections, while aov doesn't (I hardly ever use ANOVAs). I wish broom would tidy the anova_table  #rstats 

a = aov_ez("id", "rt", md_12.1, within = c("angle", "noise"))
as_tibble(a$anova_table, rownames = "term")
broom::tidy(a$aov) https://t.co/osSQycZ9ot

In the workshop, we'll learn run through some more complex examples and recreate a few of the simulation analyses from this @Meta_Psy paper using the values in Table 1.

https://t.co/FIzL2TDBrX
@JimProvost Progress on training up the 189-point delineation so far... https://t.co/s6vTtEj4gm

Then you can summarise the resulting table to calculate power or mean effect size (this example design had unrealistically huge effect sizes).

sim %>% group_by(term) %>%
  summarise(
    power = sum(`Pr(>F)` < 0.05),
    mean_ges = mean(ges)
  ) https://t.co/1YS9LBoQyz

Run the analysis on each simulated dataset.

sim <- df %>%
  mutate(analysis = lapply(data, analyse)) %>%
  select(-data) %>%
  unnest(analysis) https://t.co/OwTnI4VnKc

Define an analysis (afex::aov_ez args map onto faux::sim_design args)

analyse <- function(data) {
  afex::aov_ez(
    id = "id",
    dv = "y",
    between = "pet",
    within = "time",
    data = data,
    include_aov = F
  )$anova_table %>%
    as_tibble(rownames = "term")
}

To do a power calculation for an ANOVA analysis, simulate 100 datasets in long format:

df <- sim_design(
  within, between, 
  n = 100, mu = mu, sd = sd, r = r,
  long = TRUE, rep = 100
)

The put these together with the sim_design() function:

df <- sim_design(
  within, between, 
  n = 100, mu = mu, sd = sd, r = r
) https://t.co/4aiIK57UCu

Set parameters mu, sd, and r with vectors, data frames, or matrices:

# specify mean for each cell
mu <- data.frame(
  cat = c(10, 12, 14, 16),
  dog = c(10, 15, 20, 25),
  row.names = within$time
)

# all SD same
sd <- 5 

# get correlations from pilot data
r <- cor(pilot_data)

In faux, you set up within- and between-subject factors as lists:

between <- list(
  pet = c(cat = "Cat Owners", dog = "Dog Owners")
)

within <- list(
  time = c("morning",  "noon", "evening", "night")
)

With a standard CI, a single outlier increases the CI in both directions, but the bootstrap CI increases only in the direction of the outlier. https://t.co/aFujn9yakd

Strengths of the bootstrap + robust methods:

* Robust to heteroscedasticity
* Robust to non-normality
* Robust to outliers
* CIs can be computed for any statistic

Some recommended articles:

The Percentile Bootstrap: A Primer With Step-by-Step Instructions in R
by @robustgar @CyrilRPernet @randWilcox 
https://t.co/ZAwCs0AyPB

What Teachers Should Know about the Bootstrap
by Tim Hesterberg
https://t.co/fCla0bKwab

Benefits of teaching bootstrap methods by @robustgar 

1. Introduce or consolidate key frequentist concepts
2. Inferential stats
3. Experimental design
4. Robust statistics
5. Simulations
6. R Skills
7. Distributions of plausible population values -> Bayes

@tomstafford One thing we’re obsessed with at #psyTeachR @UofGPsychology is teaching transparent data wrangling. If you just give students clean datasets in the right format for analysis, they panic the first time they see real data. And the choices you make are important for reproducibility.

Two days until @robustgar’s bootstrapping seminar, where he will “illustrate how teaching the bootstrap is a great opportunity to introduce or consolidate key statistical concepts. ... a bootstrap distribution requires discussions about sampling and the data acquisition process.” https://t.co/MahCVMhNFJ

@tomstafford The practicalities and ethics of collaboration, like how to make sure each team members gets appropriate credit and no one is being exploited. I think most people just pick up widely varying norms as they go and it’s seldom explicitly discussed.

@djnavarro You can skip the separate with pivot_longer:

dat %>%
  mutate(id = row_number()) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !id, 
     names_to = c("var", "i"), 
     names_sep = "_") %>%
  group_by(var, id) %>%
  summarise(v = sum(value)) %>%
  spread(var, v)
@djnavarro You need to add an id column first for the later grouping.
@djnavarro Can you make completely long (so all headers in a column), split the column at the underscore, group and summarise, then make wide?

@DrLeo037 If you have, say, 20 groups, but only want the top 5 in the legend, split your data into 2 and hide 1 legend. 

ggplot(data_bottom15, aes(x,y, colour=group)) +
  geom_smooth(color =“grey”, show.legend= F) +
  geom_smooth(data = data_top5)

@DrLeo037 You can omit the legend for any individual geom like this:

geom_violin(show.legend = FALSE)

@joieprout When you knit, the displayed and ggsaved plots are the same (if the width & height are set to the same values for the plot chunk and ggsave); it's just the preview while you're running code in the source pane that is weird. Saving & displaying with knitr::include_graphics helps.

@joieprout Definitely a big frustration. It requires a bit of understanding of DPI to get an intuition for how big you should save plots. And it doesn’t help that the preview you see when working interactively in an Rmd isn’t ifentical to the saved plot.

@Letxuga007 You need to move the colour outside of aes(). The aes() function refers to the data columns that should be used to determine groups for that aesthetic, so setting it to a constant string (no matter what string), just defaults to everything in 1 group and all the default colour.

@page_gould @ibddoctor Use @ClausWilke's ggtext and html to style the caption:

ggplot(msleep, aes(vore, sleep_total)) + 
  geom_violin() +
  labs(caption = "<strong><i>Figure 1</i></strong>: My caption") +
  theme(plot.caption = ggtext::element_textbox_simple(hjust = 0)) https://t.co/tKPMFCWoaW

@ibddoctor Remove legend from a single geom like this: 

p + geom_violin(show.legend = FALSE)

Or remove all legends like this:

p + theme(legend.position = "none")

@ibddoctor Patchwork is good for combining plots with a common legend (where facet doesn't work).

p = ggplot(diamonds, aes(y = price, color = cut))
x = p + geom_smooth(aes(x = x))
y = p + geom_smooth(aes(x = y))
x + y + patchwork::plot_layout(guides = "collect")

@ajamesgreen You can put aes that are common to *all* geoms in the ggplot function, but it's a problem if an aes is specified in the default mapping that isn't relevant to a latter geom.

ggplot(diamonds, aes(cut)) +
  geom_violin(aes(y = price)) +
  geom_point(aes(y = m), data = s, size = 5)

@ajamesgreen If you're using multiple df, don't put aes() in the ggplot function, but set it separately in each geom_* function:

s = group_by(diamonds, cut) %>% summarise(m = median(price))

ggplot(diamonds) + 
  geom_violin(aes(cut, price)) +
  geom_point(aes(cut, m), data = s, size = 5)

@alexkyllo @charliejhadley The aes() function specifies which data columns define aspects of the plot, so ymin is the minimum y-axis value for geoms that span the y-axis, like errorbars (and is irrelevant to other geoms like violin).

@alexkyllo @charliejhadley All those limit functions are the same (apart from the aes one), just different way to set limits.

But it's often better to use coord_cartesian, which draws the plot with all data then crops to limits, rather than lims, which draws the plot *after* deleting data outside limits. https://t.co/acL2IOPSSU

@emma_cogdev For example, this gives the color legend the title 'Letter' and changes the labels to A and B:

scale_color_discrete(name = "Letter", labels = c("A", "B"))

This changes the x-axis to go from 1 to 10 in steps of 2:

scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1, 10), breaks = seq(1, 10, 2))

@emma_cogdev I only recently really understood how to generalise what happens in scale_{aes}_{type} functions. You can use these to change the name of an axis or legend, and also the labels for discrete values or breaks for continuous values.

So excited!! I’m going to as many of these as I can this summer (and teaching the first one). Data simulation might be the one skill I’ve learned with the most positive impact on how I understand stats and plan studies. https://t.co/xEMSMvSWyo

@somacrat I now teach it as the function that defines what data columns are represented by what aspect of the plot. E.g., to represent carats along the x-axis, price along the y-axis, and cuts as different colors, use aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut).

@ClausWilke @GracoRoza @kaiblin @stefanomammola1 In my example, I have lists of stimuli (images & associated coordinates mapping face shape). I frequently iterate over the list to process each image with parameters specified by 1 or more user-input vectors. Some of the processes are long and it would be nice to parallelize this

@emma_cogdev p = list()
p$a = ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut))
p$b = p$a + geom_point(alpha = 0.1)
p$c = p$b + geom_smooth(method = lm)
p$d = p$c + facet_wrap(~color, labeller = "label_both")
p$e = p$d + labs(x = "Weight in Carats", y = "Price in $", color = "Quality") https://t.co/jT4IspQQp5

Does anyone have tips for debugging figure references in #rmarkdown? 

Example Rmd in-text ref:
   (Fig.\ \@ref(fig:mask))

Corresponding chunk:
   ```{r mask, fig.cap="Caption"}
   plot(x)
   ```

But the rendered version is:
   (Fig. @ref(fig:mask))

Instead of:
   (Fig. 1)
